section.title: Mindquarry's Goals
section.para: The goal of the Mindquarry project is the creation of an powerful and easy-to-use collaboration environment for knowledge workers. The application should be

listitem.para: integrating the data as much as possible
make everything available in the webinterface and
provide slim desktop tools that improve the large part of the work done on your desktop

section.para: External libraries must be Open Source as well and have a compatible Open Source License.

section.title: Development Prerequisites
section.para: In order to develop Mindquarry, you need:

listitem.para: A Java Development Kit, Version 1.5 or higher
Subversion 1.3 or higher (a Subversion client is sufficient)

section.para: Additional tools for Mindquarry development that are not neccessary, but ease the development process are:

listitem.para: A good editor for Javascript and CSS

section.para: A good combination that has proven success in Mindquarry's development team is the Eclipse IDE with the Subclipse Plugin, oXygen XML Plugin and JSEclipse Javascript Editor Plugin.

section.title: Getting Mindquarry's Source Code
section.para: Mindquarry consists of many small projects (Maven modules), each with its own Subversion repository.

The easiest way to check out Mindquarry's source code is to check out the Mindquarry Meta-System, which includes all Mindquarry projects as externals. This includes everything neccessary to run the Mindquarry Webapplication.
This command will put all of Mindquarry's source code into the directory mindquarry.

section.title: Building Mindquarry
section.para: In order to build Mindquarry, run the following maven commands, starting in the mindquarry checkout directory.
# cd mindquarry-base # mvn -N install # mvn -f buildall-pom.xml installMaven will build all of Mindquarry's modules and download all dependencies neccessary for building Mindquarry.

section.title: Running Mindquarry in Development Mode
section.para: In order to run Mindquarry, you have to to build it first. Afterwards you can switch to the directory mindquarry-webapp/mindquarry-webapplication.
section.programlisting: # cd .. (going back to the mindquarry checkout directory) # cd mindquarry-webapp/mindquarry-webapplication
section.para: As a first and initial step, you have to create a comfiguration file for running Mindquarry. The easiest way to do so is copying the file config.template/mindquarry-webapplication.properties to your current working directory. Modify the parameters according to your need, eg. the directories for the data storage and the server names (typically localhost during development). The most important setting one during development is org.apache.cocoon.mode which can be either dev (=development) or prod (=production). During development you want to use dev, because it turns off caching and will directly reload the resource files like css, js, xslt etc. (but not Java code) without restarting. Using prod makes the application much more faster but needs a rebuilt of the changed modules and a restart for the changes to effect.
Then you can run mvn jetty:run to start the Mindquarry Web Application.
After a short startup time, you can open Mindquarry in your web browser at the location http://localhost:8888/. Log in as user admin with password admin and create some test data.
To shutdown the system, press CTRL+C in the console.

For subsequent restarts during development, its good to clean the build because that will delete the cache of the webapplication. Package is then needed to rebuilt the mindquarry-webapplication module before it can be started with jetty:run.

If you change any Java code, you will need to rebuilt that module (mvn install) and then restart the webapplication. For all other resources (those located in Cocoon's COB-INF directory) this is not necessary when in dev mode.

section.title: Creating Patches
section.para: In order to create patches, switch to the subdirectory of the affected module and type svn diff. After reviewing the output you can redirect the output into a patch file and send this file to bugs@mindquarry.com.
